required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study in Ovarian Cancer Patients Evaluating Rucaparib and Nivolumab as Maintenance Treatment Following Response to Front-Line Platinum-Based Chemotherapy
clinical_study.official_title: ATHENA (A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo- Controlled Phase 3 Study in Ovarian Cancer Patients Evaluating Rucaparib and Nivolumab as Maintenance Treatment Following Response to Front-Line Platinum-Based Chemotherapy)

collaborator.agency: European Network of Gynaecological Oncological Trial Groups (ENGOT)

brief_summary.textblock: This is a Phase 3, randomized, multinational, double-blind, dual placebo-controlled, 4-arm study evaluating rucaparib and nivolumab as maintenance treatment following response to front-line treatment in newly diagnosed ovarian cancer patients. Response to treatment will be analyzed based on homologous recombination (HR) status of tumor samples.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization until disease progression (up to approximately 10 years)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every ~12 weeks after the start of combination treatment for ~3 years, then every ~24 weeks thereafter until disease progression. Study data collection expected to last for ~7 years
From enrollment to primary study completion of study (up to approximately 10 years)

For patients with measurable disease, every ~12 weeks after the start of combination treatment for ~3 years, then every ~24 weeks thereafter until disease progression. Study data collection expected to last for ~7 years

For patients with measurable disease, every ~12 weeks after the start of combination treatment for ~3 years, then every ~24 weeks thereafter until disease progression. Study data collection expected to last for ~7 years

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with treatment-emergent Adverse Events (AEs) as assessed by CTCAE v4 (or higher) as a measure of safety and tolerability
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected from the time patient receives first dose of study drug until post treatment safety follow-up period (up to approximately 10 years)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with serious AEs as a measure of safety and tolerability
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected from the time patient receives first dose of study drug until post treatment safety follow-up period (up to approximately 10 years)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with laboratory abnormalities as a measure of safety and tolerability
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected from the time patient receives first dose of study drug until post treatment safety follow-up period (up to approximately 10 years)

intervention.description: Oral rucaparib will be administered twice daily
IV nivolumab will be administered once every 4 weeks
Placebo tablets will be administered twice daily
IV placebo will be administered once every 4 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Newly diagnosed advanced (FIGO stage III-IV) epithelial ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer.
- Completed cytoreductive surgery, including at least a bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and partial omentectomy, either prior to chemotherapy (primary surgery) or following neoadjuvant chemotherapy (interval debulking)
- Completed first-line platinum-based chemotherapy and surgery with a response, in the opinion of the Investigator
- Sufficient tumor tissue for planned analysis
- ECOG performance status of 0 or 1
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pure sarcomas or borderline tumors or mucinous tumors
- Active second malignancy
- Known central nervous system brain metastases
- Any prior treatment for ovarian cancer, other than the first-line platinum regimen
- Evidence of interstitial lung disease or active pneumonitis
- Active, known or suspected autoimmune disease
- Condition requiring active systemic treatment with either corticosteroids (>10 mg daily prednisone equivalent) or other immunosuppressive medications

contact.last_name: Rebecca Kristeleit, Msc, MBChB, FRCP, PhD
